author: Jane Levere
title: Creators, Original Cast Members Of 'Into the Woods' Reunite 28 Years After Musical's Broadway Debut - Forbes
text:
The original cast of Into the Woods —the 1987 Broadway musical by James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim made into a film released last year starring Meryl Streep , Anna Kendrick and Johnny Depp , among others—reunited with its creators at the Brooklyn Academy of Music earlier this month, sharing stories about the first production and their involvement with it.
Lapine said Sondheim pitched the concept of a TV show featuring characters from Doctor Kildare , Father Knows Best and I Love Lucy , in a hospital to producer Norman Lear Lear ; Lapine said Lear “loved it” and asked to see a script—which didn’t exist–that he would try to sell. Lapine called Sondheim’s conversation with Lear “time well-spent,” an inspiration for Into the Woods.
Lapine said he wrote an “endless” opening scene–featuring characters from the Brothers Grimm fairy tales “Little Red Riding Hood,” “Jack and the Beanstalk” and “Cinderella”—and gave it Sondheim, “not knowing how he’d musicalize this. He took it, and, boom. . . After the opening number, we could ride with it.”
Sondheim said he tried to get into “the playwright’s mind. I do exactly what the actor does, I look at the dialogue and delve as deeply as I can.”
Joanna Gleason, who portrayed the baker’s wife and won Tony and other awards for her performance, said that she felt confused by her character’s seduction by Cinderella’s prince, telling Sondheim she felt like she was in the “wrong story.” Sondheim said this was the only time in his life he took lyrics from an actor (in “Any Moment,” the baker’s wife sings to the prince, ”What am I doing here? I’m in the wrong story.“)
Lapine mentioned that Kim Crosby, Cinderella in the original production, had winning America’s Junior Miss pageant on her resume. “This woman was for real, she has a purity and innocence, she’s from Missouri,” he explained, adding that Patti Lupone, not known for these virtues, also auditioned for the role.
Similarly, Lapine said he saw Ben Wright—who originated the role of Jack—“sitting with a big smile on his face. He had this Midwestern thing, innocence and purity, an innocence in his voice.”
The creators and members of the original cast of the Broadway musical, “Into the Woods,” reunited recently at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. (Richard Termine)
Bernadette Peters, the witch in the original production, and a star, with Mandy Patinkin, in Lapine’s and Sondheim’s earlier musical, Sunday in the Park with George , called working on the musical with Patinkin “a great experience about learning about life.” She said she felt there would be more “life lessons” from Into the Woods, adding that she wanted to “learn, because Steve writes music and lyrics that are able to say what he wants to say.”
